Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Cooperative Routing in Wireless Ad- Hoc Networks with Advanced PHY Layers: Interference Management, Resource Allocation, and Information Mixing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless ad-hoc networks consist solely of cheap, mobile nodes that operate in the absence of expensive fixed infrastructure such as base stations. In order to save energy, increase data rate, or improve robustness, some nodes may act as helper nodes, relaying some or all of the information. In the simplest form of relaying, data packets are forwarded node-by-node in a manner akin to a fire bucket brigade. In more advanced methods, such as those considered in this research, several nodes can cooperate to forward information. The key design questions are two-fold. First is the design of cooperative communication techniques, i.e., physical-layer approaches for relaying information from one set of nodes to the next. Second is routing, i.e., identifying which of the available nodes should participate in the transmission and what system resources (time, energy, bandwidth) should be allocated to each.

This research analyzes interconnections between these two key questions, treated separately in most prior work. We consider the routing problem when rateless codes are employed at the physical layer. Such codes allow receiving nodes to accumulate mutual information (instead of just energy) from multiple transmitting nodes. This yields greater network robustness and efficiency. The research investigates the effect of interference, which automatically arises when multiple messages are being transmitted simultaneously. By using stochastic network optimization, optimum resource allocation can be provided without the need for centralized knowledge of all states of nodes and propagation channels. Cooperative transmission techniques based on a hybrid of network-coding and compute-and-forward, their rateless variants, and application to cooperative routing are investigated as well. The concepts are validated through experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless multi-hop ad-hoc networks have drawn significant attention in recent years, due to their flexibility and low cost, and their resulting importance in factory automation, sensor networks, security systems, and many other applications. A fundamental problem in such networks is the scheduling of network resources and data routing, i.e., which nodes should transmit which data stream in which direction using which amount of resource. The throughput performance becomes an issue when a single stream or multiple streams of packets intended for a single destination or multiple destinations (i.e., multiple commodities) flow through a network. 

A central aspect of our work was the concept of "Mutual Information Accumulation" (MIA). In essence, this means that when a wireless node receives a transmission, it might not get the complete information that would allow it to properly decode and process a data packet, but just a part of it. In traditional ad-hoc networks, a "partial" reception of a packet is deemed a failure, and the transmission starts from scratch. In MIA, the receiving node stores the parts it could hear properly, and aims to get more info when the packet is repeated. This is similar to a conversation over a bad phone line: there is always a chance that a word is missed because of static on the line; obviously it is much more efficient to repeat just this one word, then to have to repeat the whole last sentence. Now in multi-hop networks, using MIA for transmission from one node to the other changes also how the packet should be routed over the network.

A considerable part of our work focused on how to commpute the best routes in such an MIA network. We presented a method for finding such optimum routes, but also proved rigorously that networks with MIA perform better than networks with simple "repetition coding" (the simple approach described above), which is the state of the art. In our background work, we had developed the Diversity Backpressure Routing (DIVBAR) Algorithm, which exploits the broadcast nature of the wireless medium, for maximizing throughput in multi-hop wireless networks with unreliable channels and multiple traffic streams with repetition coding. In this project, therefore, we further generalized the DIVBAR algorithm by keeping transmitting each single copy of packet using MIA and developed two algorithms: the DIVBAR-RMIA algorithm and the DIVBAR-FMIA algorithm. 

DIVBAR is based on a stochastic network optimization, when only the average channel quality, but not the instantaneous variations are known. For routing with MIA  when all channel state are known, we built on our preliminary work to develop more efficient algorithms both for unicast and broadcast.

Another way to exploit the MIA is  when receivers cooperatively combine their information to transmit to the intended destimation. This idea is different than “rateless coding” but involves similar accumulation techniques. Similar to rateless coding, it also redefines the nature of a “packet.” Our work showed, inter alia, how to optimally schedule using this cooperative coding strategy in a 2-hop network. Further work builds on this cooperation idea in a cognitive radio context.
